notes: Scope: non-pregnant women aged 16–64 years with suspected lower UTI. Exclude men, pregnant individuals, urological abnormalities, catheters, recurrent UTIs (>=2 in 6 months or >=3 in 12 months), and recent nitrofurantoin use (<3 months).
Encourage patients to bring midstream urine only if advised; diagnosis is symptom-based using the three key signs (dysuria, new nocturia, cloudy urine).

Remind patients to increase fluid intake, avoid delaying voiding, and consider paracetamol/ibuprofen for pain. Provide the TARGET UTI leaflet and document safety-netting (urgent review if fever, flank pain, vomiting).
Nitrofurantoin is first-line unless eGFR <45 mL/min, suspected pyelonephritis, or other contraindications; ensure no allergy and review medicines for interactions.
Advise sexual health screening if vaginal discharge or STI risk factors present; refer immunosuppressed patients to GP.

decisionTree.title: Consider risk of deterioration or sepsis
decisionTree.question: Does the patient have sepsis risk factors (fever, rigors, tachycardia, hypotension, rapidly worsening systemic symptoms)?

sepsisSigns: New confusion, mottled skin, cold extremities
Unable to stay awake or hypotension

yes.title: Urgent referral
actions: Call 999/A&E or arrange immediate GP review using NEWS2 guidance.
Do not supply antibiotics under PGD; monitor vitals while awaiting transfer.

no.title: Assess for pyelonephritis
no.question: Are there new signs/symptoms of pyelonephritis?

pyeloSigns: New onset fever ≥38 °C or shaking chills

yes.title: Urgent same-day referral
actions: Refer to GP or urgent care for upper UTI management (possible IV therapy).
Advise patient to seek hospital care if unable to access GP promptly.

yes.title: Onward referral
actions: Refer to GP, sexual health clinic or specialist as appropriate.
Provide self-care advice and document reason for referral.

no.title: Gateway point
no.question: Does the patient have ≥1 of the three key diagnostic symptoms?

keySymptoms: New nocturia (needing to pass urine at night)
Urine cloudy to the naked eye

next.title: UTI less likely
actions: Explore other causes (STI, vaginal infection, interstitial cystitis).
Provide self-care, encourage hydration, and refer if symptoms persist.

next.title: UTI equally likely to other diagnoses
actions: Consider urine dipstick or culture if accessible, or refer for GP testing.
Offer self-care advice and advise review if symptoms worsen or persist.
next.followUp: Ask patient to seek GP review if no improvement in 48 hours.

severityGuidance: Mild symptoms without systemic features: encourage self-care first.
Moderate/severe symptoms or patient preference: consider immediate antibiotic.

next.title: Self-care and delayed review
actions: Provide TARGET UTI leaflet, encourage fluids and analgesia.
Arrange pharmacist review if symptoms not improving in 48 hours.
next.followUp: Ask patient to return in 48 hours if no improvement for reassessment.

next.title: Nitrofurantoin (first line)

dose.Adults: 100 mg modified-release capsule twice daily (every 12 hours)
dose.Alternative regimen: 50 mg immediate-release tablets/capsules four times daily

plus: Contraindicated if eGFR <45 mL/min or suspected upper UTI.
Advise that urine may turn yellow/brown; this is harmless.
Complete 3-day course even if symptoms improve early.
next.followUp: If no improvement within 48 hours of starting antibiotics, arrange GP review.
